    Week 1: Reading Reflection

    Josh Scanlan
    Jan 14, 2016 at 6:55pm
    44 44 unread replies. 163 163 replies.

    Part of innovation is taking what you experience -- including what you read -- and thinking about the missing pieces, the next steps, or just something you are curious about.  Most weeks we will ask you to do so with one or more of the readings from that week by generating 2-3 questions that arise for you from that reading.  We will allot class time to further deepen our understanding of the readings via these questions.  

    This week, as you read the assigned readings, identify 2-3 questions that you would like to discuss related to the reading, particularly about the relationships among the readings, similarities and differences.  You might have your own favorite stories about innovation.  Feel free to post them as well. Post your response in the Discussions section of bCourses no later than Wednesday at 2:00 p.m., 24 hours before the start of class.  The Discussions page aims to give you a chance to interact widely with your classmates around the readings, so once you have posted your own questions, please react and respond to at least two of your classmates’ posts.  As we will use the discussion forum throughout the class, here are some guidelines for doing so:

    Be thoughtful, constructive and inclusive.  In your responses, be kind, present objectives or different points of view open to the possibility that there may be a reasonable response, and object to theses rather than to people.  Objections are fine, but you can also choose to be constructive, and you needn't repeat the same objection multiple times.  Be inclusive in your contributions, acknowledging previous contributions, avoiding unnecessarily offensive examples.  It is perfectly alright to raise questions that may seem to you to be unsophisticated or uninformed.  This is a place to learn and explore.

     

    This topic was locked May 5, 2016 at 11:59pm.

        Collapse Subdiscussion KEVIN KIM

        KEVIN KIM

        Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11:44am
        1a. Is innovation partly thinking in a larger frame? Is thinking of the details often a hinderance in a creative process? What is the limit to the large frame then? 1b. In reference to "Backpack Makers Rethink Student Sample" and ghanathinktank, they both suggest mentally moving out from the original frame to create new ideas - does that mean moving onto a larger frame, or into a new one altogether (or both)? 2. In reference to Outside the Citadel, Social Practice Art Is Intended to Nurture, can art be redefined as not only a product meant to engage an audience, but more broadly some tangible or intangible factor utilized to evoke emotions and spread messages? This reminds me of Social Cognition, a course that taught me of different "mental lenses." More specifically, how one frames any concept alters how it is viewed and utilized. I feel this article was targeting the idea of pushing boundaries, changing the Western "mental lenses" towards art in general. Moreover, it also reminded me of "? + ? = 10" concept in Tuesday's class - the possibilities, though it may be limited, are still more than one.

        1a. Is innovation partly thinking in a larger frame? Is thinking of the details often a hinderance in a creative process? What is the limit to the large frame then?

        1b. In reference to "Backpack Makers Rethink Student Sample" and ghanathinktank, they both suggest mentally moving out from the original frame to create new ideas - does that mean moving onto a larger frame, or into a new one altogether (or both)?

        2. In reference to Outside the Citadel, Social Practice Art Is Intended to Nurture, can art be redefined as not only a product meant to engage an audience, but more broadly some tangible or intangible factor utilized to evoke emotions and spread messages? This reminds me of Social Cognition, a course that taught me of different "mental lenses." More specifically, how one frames any concept alters how it is viewed and utilized. I feel this article was targeting the idea of pushing boundaries, changing the Western "mental lenses" towards art in general. Moreover, it also reminded me of "? + ? = 10" concept in Tuesday's class - the possibilities, though it may be limited, are still more than one.

              DJ Kool Herc asked other hip hop artists to help raise his son. What is art, performance, and business' role in shaping society? How can collaboration in these and other fields be a positive influence on younger generations? How much focus should be placed on impacting youth?   Many people view art as a way to express emotions and ideas. How can art be further used to make changes in the way institutions and society operate?  What are more ways art and performance can move from the abstract and analysis side of the innovation cycle to the synthesis side?

              DJ Kool Herc asked other hip hop artists to help raise his son. What is art, performance, and business' role in shaping society? How can collaboration in these and other fields be a positive influence on younger generations? How much focus should be placed on impacting youth?

               

              Many people view art as a way to express emotions and ideas. How can art be further used to make changes in the way institutions and society operate?  What are more ways art and performance can move from the abstract and analysis side of the innovation cycle to the synthesis side?

                              Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 7:39pm
                              Let me rephrase: I feel as though some animosity exists between artists who practice traditional media and those who engage in social practice. As the article noted, some painters feel as though social practice artists look down upon traditional/ graphic design artists. Likewise, I think social practice artists feel as though they constantly have to defend and legitmize their chosen mode of making.  Perhaps more collaboration between the two groups of artists would help ease tensions.

                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Stephanie Syjuco

                                  Stephanie Syjuco

                                  Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 10:17pm
                                  I get what you mean by your question now, Merissa. There is some truth in your observation -- it's not so much animosity that exists between artists that practice these differing forms, but a healthy suspicion by more established traditional models of art making on what social practice "is" and why it's even considered "art". I think that's slowly fading, but it's a similar question that lots of other students are appearing to ask in this discussion thread. It makes sense in a way -- the forms are unfamiliar and it departs from an aesthetic treatment that most people rely on when thinking about what art "should look like." The nice thing is that there are actually a lot of artists who overlap their practice and don't stick with being strictly painters, sculptors, social practice, etc. So maybe it's not necessarily more collaboration that needs to happen (or is already happening), but more artists working diversely. Or, to play devil's advocate, maybe it's also OK for everyone to specialize in their field and have a healthy respect for those who specialize in another field!

In light of these differing reasons for innovation, do businesses innovations still have social merit?   Do you believe that highly conceptual artistic interventions can or do bring about concrete change?                                   I'm going to push back on your question number one with another question: does the primary source of motivation invalidate any or all effects beyond the motivating ones? I'm inclined to think that one can't generalize to the merit of all businesses' innovations, and instead would have to judge each's social merit based on what effects they actually have on people.

                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Donovan Souza

                                      Donovan Souza

                                      Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:45pm
                                      @Merissa's #1: Business innovations motivated by profit can have social merit or positive externalities. It may be profitable for a company to manufacture electric cars, thus reducing emissions. Same with solar panels, mass recycling, etc. On the flip side, business innovations motivated by profit can have negative externalities, such as water and noise pollution. @Abigail: It certainly doesn't invalidate the effects of an action. Your answer made me think of my Legal Studies 151 class on philosophy (specifically Kantianism and Consequentialism). I agree that we should ultimately look at the consequences of an action to decide whether or not the action/innovation was good or had social merit, but we run into a problem where we may need to decide if an action/innovation is net beneficial before it happens, without having a concrete idea about what might happen.

                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Sara BECKMAN

                                          Sara BECKMAN

                                          Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 8:56am
                                          This is a very interesting conversation.  As a faculty we started a conversation about "value" and how we measure the value of our respective work.  In the business world, there is a lot of talk about the "integrated bottom line" of financial, social and environmental performance.  While there is along way to go in achieving this integration, at least some businesses are striving to make it work.  There is also increasing talk about a shift from the "production - consumption dyad" where I focus on producing something that I hand over in return for money to a "creation of value in use" model that is said to underpin the "sharing economy".  The latter provides opportunities for rethinking the business models we use, and for potentially redistributing value in different ways.  I hope we'll talk about this much more as the semester progresses!

                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Catherine Cole

                                            Catherine Cole

                                            Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11:44am
                                            I really appreciate your question #1: what are the values that drive the the innovation process in respective domains: financial profit? efficiency? effectiveness? developing a new market? meeting an otherwise unmet need? Businesses may have many different values operating at once, with the "bottom line" being a driver, yes, but not the only driver--especially so in non-profit organizations.  In terms of art, some artists want to make social change, yes, but others are allergic to that idea and feel it degrades art to think in those terms ("art for arts sake," etc.) Here's what one scholar has to say about art:  “Art-making is an experiment in conjuring up the possibilities that are hidden in the habitual and the familiar. The practice of art is for this reason akin to prophecy: however much it is embedded in the past, in rules and conventions and traditions, its deepest commitment is to the future."—Stephen Greenblatt So perhaps what our class can help frame is an awareness about what values are implicit or explicit in different domains and projects, especially in the "convergent" process of design. When we winnow multiple options down to one, why do certain ideas emerge as the "best"? 
                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                            • Go To Parent

                                            I really appreciate your question #1: what are the values that drive the the innovation process in respective domains: financial profit? efficiency? effectiveness? developing a new market? meeting an otherwise unmet need? Businesses may have many different values operating at once, with the "bottom line" being a driver, yes, but not the only driver--especially so in non-profit organizations.  In terms of art, some artists want to make social change, yes, but others are allergic to that idea and feel it degrades art to think in those terms ("art for arts sake," etc.) Here's what one scholar has to say about art: 

                                            “Art-making is an experiment in conjuring up the possibilities that are hidden in the habitual and the familiar. The practice of art is for this reason akin to prophecy: however much it is embedded in the past, in rules and conventions and traditions, its deepest commitment is to the future."—Stephen Greenblatt

                                            So perhaps what our class can help frame is an awareness about what values are implicit or explicit in different domains and projects, especially in the "convergent" process of design. When we winnow multiple options down to one, why do certain ideas emerge as the "best"?

                                                                  Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:54am
                                                                  -While the book "Service Innovation Handbook Forward" suggests "Designing is about specifics" (5), Mr. Rothenhaus from the article "Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple" exhibits his experience of "research steered us away from trying to design pockets and compartments for specific uses." Regarding the opposing ideas proposed in readings, is there an ideal definition of or approach to designs? If there is, should we aim toward the "specific" or not? -Rakowitz's paraSITE and DJ Kool Herc's ethics presented in his book "Can't Stop Won't Stop" seem to share a keyword in common: "ghetto" (13). I was taught culture is a thing that majority of people are accustomed to. However, these two artists counter-argued with their works presenting voice of under-representatives. Definition of culture, is it truly what majority follows? If not, what is the definition of a culture?

                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Sara BECKMAN

                                                                      Sara BECKMAN

                                                                      Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 9:09am
                                                                      Great identification of a seeming contradiction!  Let's use Apple to answer your question.  Apple pays close attention to all of the details of your experience -- whether in the store or with the products themselves.  But, it doesn't design a bunch of different phones for a bunch of different user segments.  When Kimbell talks about specifics, she means paying close attention to people and what will work best for them.  When Rothenhaus talks about specifics, he is saying that one has to be careful not to design for too narrow a segment.  Khan Academy is another great example -- as we discussed in class yesterday Khan can be customized for use in many different circumstances, but is not specifically designed for each of them.  Customizability is at the heart of this dichotomy!

                                                                            Paige Davis

                                                                            Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 9:59am
                                                                            I find it interesting that the JanSport team uses the term “third spaces” to describe “the cafe tables or park benches that become impromptu work spaces.” Last semester I was introduced to Edward Soja’s concept of “thirdspace,” which seems to be what JanSport is referring to -- “the space we give meaning to. . .the experience of living,” a space where “everything comes together” such as the real and the imagined, the abstract and the concrete. Does this term thirdspace make sense when speaking about social-practice art, or art in general; are most artists (most innovators, designers...) trying to make sense of the thirdspace? Are the ThinkTanks or hip-hop or paraSITE examples of thirdspace/what we can do with thirdspace?   Why is art so difficult to define? Is there a better term that could be used for “art” that might make people more open to how varied art can be? Or is it really art anymore if it has a different name? Interesting that we have the term social-practice art. Does this imply that “social-practice art” must be termed social-practice for it to be accepted as a kind of art, not art in essence?   “People want to stay more connected socially, even in the outdoors. . .Even if they’re in the back country, they’re using solar panels, GoPros, GPS.” The “outdoors” is becoming innovated? What is the purpose of bringing innovation when on a hike or on a backpacking trip, etc? Is the purpose to be more socially connected working? What is the outdoors -- is the meaning changing? Is it a thirdspace?

                                                                                Clarissa Yeung

                                                                                Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 10:51am
                                                                                For your third question, Paige, I think innovation has different meanings when considered in various contexts. If we think from the perspective of outdoor gears producers, innovation should be catalyzed by the need to cater to clients' needs. As our world grows increasingly digitalized, bringing social connection to the gears not only fulfills this need, but this action may end up suggesting new ideas to clients who might not have known their need for outdoor connections in the first place. In this case, businesses are innovating the way clients think and create an alternative culture. Is the outdoors being innovated? I would say that the way backpackers/ hikers think of their needs and their experience outdoor is being innovated.

                                                                                              Lydia Pollard

                                                                                              Jan 21, 2016 Jan 21, 2016 at 12:31pm
                                                                                              The "third space" is an important concept, and is rapidly changing with innovations in technology.  The outdoors were formerly a space to interact with strangers.  It was the opportunity for the high levels of interaction with those from varied backgrounds.  By innovating outdoor space, we are making it easier shut out these interactions by staying connected to others on devices.  It is possible that in these situations, we are potentially giving up a lot in exchange for convenience.

                                                                                                    Great question.  Does it come down to how you define "value"?  I think defining value is core to framing the problem you want to solve.  Are you aiming to bring attention to homelessness, to get rid of homelessness, to make homelessness a little more tolerable, etc.?  These are all different frames around the more general issue of homelessness, and adopting each one will lead you to different solutions, ideas, concepts.  This is like the $5/2 hour exercise.  How you frame the opportunity dictates what ideas you come up with.

                                                                                                                  Abigail Landers

                                                                                                                  Jan 19, 2016 Jan 19, 2016 at 11:42pm
                                                                                                                  I think your interpretation of the meaning of the think tank video is really interesting. I got something completely different out of it. I read something recently that described a fictional situation where a young Nigerian college student has heard that the US has a gun violence problem. She thinks this problem could easily be solved if the US would simply take the guns away. After graduating, she travels to the US for a year to implement her solution, and finds once she's here that the solution isn't so simple, because of the political climate, the cultural relationship that Americans have with guns, etc. The point of the parable being that people can't presume to have the simple solution to a foreign problem. And it usually takes this role reversal to make it obvious that a lot of American students aspire to the equivalent of the Nigerian anti-guns activist. I thought that this think tank, at least in part, seemed like the same sort of thing.

                                                                                                                      That's a good analysis Abigail -- Ghana Thinktank is an artist collaborative project made by ex-NGO workers. Their experiences on the ground made them realize how designing "solutions" for others can be problematic and assumes many things that are way more complicated in reality. Linking to their "about" page on the website gives more information about their motivations: http://www.ghanathinktank.org/about "Ghana ThinkTank’s innovative approach to public art reveals blind spots between otherwise disconnected cultures, challenges assumptions about who is “needy,” and turns the idea of expertise on its head by asking people in the “third world” to solve problems of people in the “first world.” This process helps people overcome their own stereotypes while being exposed to the stereotypes that other cultures have about them."

                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Stephanie Syjuco

                                                                                                                            Stephanie Syjuco

                                                                                                                            Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11:27am
                                                                                                                            Hi Parmida, good questions... One of the benefits and interesting problems of paraSITE is that as an artist project, Rakowitz purposely decided to not ask for permission and even took into account local laws to see how he could circumvent them (click through some of the images on the project site to get to the part with the policeman). I think his main motivation was to: 1.) treat the homeless as actual individual "clients" and customize their temporary living units to their needs, 2.) circumvent traditional models of approval in order to address an urgent and pressing need to warm people on urban streets (not wait for other solutions from a slow or negligent city planning department), and 3.) create a startling and functional visual rupture on city streets to actually highlight issues of homelessness. Politically-engaged artworks such as this one sometimes sidestep traditional models of approval and display, in order to move forward with their ideas.Not sure how dangerous hooking up to specific HVAC systems are, but I would like to assume he researched this and took this into account... More online research on his project for you, maybe?

I think his main motivation was to: 1.) treat the homeless as actual individual "clients" and customize their temporary living units to their needs, 2.) circumvent traditional models of approval in order to address an urgent and pressing need to warm people on urban streets (not wait for other solutions from a slow or negligent city planning department), and 3.) create a startling and functional visual rupture on city streets to actually highlight issues of homelessness. Politically-engaged artworks such as this one sometimes sidestep traditional models of approval and display, in order to move forward with their ideas.

                                                                                                                                With regards to Rakowitz's motivations, specifically the one you listed as (3,), is there any way to measure how successful this was? Or is it possible that the craftiness and innovation of socially engaging works sometimes steal the spotlight away from the actual issue at hand? For example, on his website, the slideshow of images places a lot of emphasis on the design and how he himself as the designer, accommodated the needs of his 'clients'. What do you think about this?

                                                                                                                                  Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11:49am
                                                                                                                                  I would agree that using the outtake HVAC system vents was dangerous, but I believe that the danger is worth it if the end result proves to be beneficial. We played with atoms, not knowing if they would end the world in a seemingly infinite fission process. However, there is obviously a difference between experimentation in the lab and a more social/consumer oriented issue. Obviously, we don't make new food or products and feed it to a bunch of people to see what happens, but attempt to follow a process that doesn't endanger anyone in a testing process. Perhaps that's why it hasn't "caught on".

                                                                                                                                                    Paige Davis

                                                                                                                                                    Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:22pm
                                                                                                                                                    I want to reply to, but not necessarily answer your first question, with an example that may use education to showcase social practice. I'm from Santa Cruz and there's a museum there (Museum of Art and History, MAH) that tries to be more involved in the community than a more traditional museum. They have children and family activities before show openings that try to get young people interested in art and history (a lot of the shows are locally oriented), they have a team of teenagers -- volunteers, I believe -- that plan museum events, and there are a lot of events that are aimed to invite the community to participate. This is obviously not a large institution -- Santa Cruz is a small town -- and the MAH isn't perfect; it may not be giving back to the same community that it is trying to draw, if that makes sense. I don't know enough about it to say more or critique it, but I think that they're working on a really interesting and smart way -- rethinking what a museum is -- to have people begin to value art that is more community oriented, and/or to see community events as artworks.

                                                                                                                                                        Clarissa Yeung

                                                                                                                                                        Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 10:36am
                                                                                                                                                        I think both of your questions are very interesting, Alina. In response to question 2, I think the majority of innovative ideas are the results of necessity.  In fact, I consider creativity as the derivative of the necessity of functional and relevant changes. As a capitalist economy, our society is comprised mainly of institutions and businesses that are financially driven because they simply can't survive without generating profits. And out of the necessity to maintain their competitiveness in the market, constant innovation is required to ensure that their products and services can adapt to social changes. Should innovation be spurred by necessity or by sparks of creativity? This is a difficult question to answer, but I would say that with the context of our society nowadays, necessity tends to be the motivation behind innovation. After all , without capital obtained through economic activities, how do we support any actualization of creativity?

                                                                                                                                                            Sara BECKMAN

                                                                                                                                                            Jan 21, 2016 Jan 21, 2016 at 11:09am
                                                                                                                                                            Interesting question about "necessity" versus "sparks of creativity".  Were you inspired by the backpacks that they developed?  Personally, I felt a little underwhelmed...like they were missing some "creativity."  Sometimes we talk about needs at the levels of use, usability and meaning.  In this case it feels like they focused on use and usability -- the functionality and use of the backpack -- and not so much on the emotional connection to it.  Creativity often arises more around "meaning"!  I think that's what you are hearing from the art practice and theater folks...but it it important in business as well -- think about Apple products -- they go well beyond use and usability!

                                                                                                                                                                                Sara BECKMAN

                                                                                                                                                                                Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 9am
                                                                                                                                                                                Fun questions.  I like to think about three levels of needs: use, usability and meaning.  Fulfilling use-based needs means providing the basic functionality that is needed (e.g., my computer fits in my backpack).  Fulfilling usability-based needs means providing easy access to the functionality (e.g., the pack is comfortable to carry).  Fulfilling meaning-based needs (which is what Amanda and Stephanie referred to a lot yesterday) means understanding the emotional connection to the solution (e.g., how I feel when I wear it, what I look like when I wear it, what "story" it allows me to belong to when I wear it).  A good products meets the needs at all three levels in an integrated way.  We'll talk a lot more about this!  
                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                Fun questions.  I like to think about three levels of needs: use, usability and meaning.  Fulfilling use-based needs means providing the basic functionality that is needed (e.g., my computer fits in my backpack).  Fulfilling usability-based needs means providing easy access to the functionality (e.g., the pack is comfortable to carry).  Fulfilling meaning-based needs (which is what Amanda and Stephanie referred to a lot yesterday) means understanding the emotional connection to the solution (e.g., how I feel when I wear it, what I look like when I wear it, what "story" it allows me to belong to when I wear it).  A good products meets the needs at all three levels in an integrated way.  We'll talk a lot more about this!

                                                                                                                                                                                    Christine Nguyen

                                                                                                                                                                                    Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11:47am
                                                                                                                                                                                    1. As I look on campus, I noticed that many students are invested in Longchamps, Hershels, or other "high end" looking backpacks, and so I feel as if the quality and appearance matters more than the function of backpacks. For example, no one where crocs anymore, but many people wear Birkenstocks, due to it's quality and appearance.  2. It definitely depends on the person because everyone has different needs. For me, I focus more on the quality, then the appearance and finally, the function.  3. Being an art major, I think everything is art. For me, everything starts with a design, which branches off of art. I do not prefer to keep the purity of art, such as paintings and drawings. Instead, I want to know how far art can go, such as 3-D printing and designing. I want art to become more of a social work and help others so that people could stop saying that "art is useless."

                                                                                                                                                                                        I believe it to be a combination of both where style and function meet. And while I would personally like a bag to look great, I also need to make sure I can fit my sneakers and laptop in the same space.  I struggle with this big business mentality. I understand the need to drive sales up, but I also come from the school that believes in quality over quantity.

                                                                                                                                                                                                      Jiachen Hu

                                                                                                                                                                                                      Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 1:54pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                      Hi Eunice, for your first question, I would say a way doesn't necessarily exist, or we might have too many ways at the same time. There seems to be no best way to compare two ideas, whether which one is better, more valuable, more innovative...However we are comparing ideas in really life all the time and most of the time able to make a choice. The way we do it is to compare them in strict scale, scenario and standards and with limited parameters. To answer how we know which one is better, we can't answer if we are seeking for absolute answer, but we can put them in the specific situations, and then apply the analysis we use everyday: profit, efficiency, practicability and so on.

                                                                                                                                                                                                              Harneet Kaur

                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 26, 2016 Feb 26, 2016 at 12:19pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                              I thought the Ghana Think Tank  project is a great exercise in perspective.  While people in first world countries might consider their problems of "dreaming about sex" or "getting old and fat" to be tragic and damaging issues, when compared with the problems that a developing country's citizen might face (little access to clean water, women's rights, etc) they often pale in comparison.  That's not to say, that we should de-legitimatize the problems faced in 1st world countries just because "someone, somewhere has it worse" but that we should approach them with a grain of salt and perhaps step back and consider just how "agonizing" they might be.   To answer to your question, I think the third world countrymen and women probably think first world issues are petty and superficial compared to their own.  Often, third world countries are collectivist and have stronger traditions/social systems in place to deal with issues like "respecting elders" or "finding yourself" and so they are able to surpass these issues with ease. And while we might criticize them for their lack of emphasis on the individual, their mindsets help them circumvent a lot of first world problems with ease.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Paige Davis

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 1:27pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    In response to your first question, Paublo Helguera says that it is difficult to critique the success of a socially engaged art work, because there are many ways to have a socially engaged art work and it is going to be different for everyone. I wonder if it is even necessary to try to measure the success. Helguera says that it's up to the critics to decide what's successful, but does one need to critique/measure the success of an art form? What type of success? Perhaps it is important to measure if we are curious about how many people it reached and in what way, but it seems impossible to develop a single way to critique the successes of different artworks. I also don't think that socially-engaged art compromises the visual/emotional value of art. Just because an art work is more accessible doesn't degrade it, it can be seen as being even more beautiful because more people -- not just traditionally the upper class -- can see and can feel an emotional response to it.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 10:13am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                "Outside the Citadel," Education for Socially Engaged Art,and the Ghana Think Tank video all provided insight into / examples of how the boundaries of creating art have become blurrier and how art is increasingly "not about art." What does this mean? What was art (supposed to be) about? Is it the strokes, lines, ratios, colors, and such? (Excuse me; I don't really know what I'm talking about! Haven't delved into art as a subject much!)   And does it matter: Does it matter that art is now so much more service than aesthetics? Is it for better or for worse? I would imagine that it's better: there is more progress in society when art is a medium or tool we can use to reach out a helping hand to people in need, coming up with solutions to problems. And it makes it so art is not such "an isolated world," as mentioned in "Outside the citadel." But does it detract from the aesthetic, historical, cultural, or other value of art in forms we are more familiar with?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Stephanie Syjuco

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Stephanie Syjuco

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Hi Irene, these are great questions! Your question "What was art (supposed to be) about?" is a good one that is even wrestled with amongst art practitioners and the artworld itself. The answer has changed over time, and depends on how society wants it to function -- on a larger philosophical context it encompasses all of human cultural expression, and that's a great thing. It's accessible, involves play, curiosity, and investigation. But on a commercial and institutional level it has come to equate high priced commodities, elite institutions, and rarified aesthetics. Think of it similar to how music works: everyone can play music in some way (although not necessarily consider themselves "musical" or even "musicians." There are concerts in the park, individual musicians making work, etc. And that's different from the music "industry," which turns it into a packaged commodity. Social practice artists in many ways are attempting to make artwork and artmaking more accessible and engaged with the public, and less locked up in galleries and museums. Another way to think about it is that "art" is a very diverse form, much like music. It can encompass its own versions of hiphop, opera, classical, country, rock, pop, punk, and experimental noise. So art can have things like performance, paintings, sculptures, social practice, video, conceptual projects, etc. They make for a rich and diverse expression/investigation of human culture. Social practice will not supplant other, more visually aesthetic or traditional forms of art, it's just one way artists are responding to the world around them.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Parent

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        On a related note, there was one time when hiphop and rap were not considered music. There were huge debates about this! Imagine if they could see things now... Some art forms enter into a recognizable canon at different times, and for different reasons. There was also a time when photography wasn't considered an art form because it was just "a machine making images" and not hand-drawn by an artist. It sounds so quaint now, but these were serious issues then.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I enjoyed all of the readings, stories and videos. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        My most favorite story about innovation was "paraSITE". I found it extremely innovative that it started with an idea that not only helps the homeless, but how they were able to create it out of trash bags and zip blog bags. I also really like how they can fit two people within the inflatable shelter and how five dollars can build a movable and changeable home for them and all they needed was to add onto a heating vent. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The only questions that I had was:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        1) How do you compare "paraSITE" innovation of inflatable shelters to the Service Innovation Handbook Forward that we read?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        2) How does Ghana Think Tank connect with  "Can't Stop Won't Stop Introduction?"

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        3) What does "Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple,"paraSITE, Service Innovation Handbook have in common?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 12, 2016 Feb 12, 2016 at 12:44pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            I agree paraSITE may have to be one of my favorites that we read for this week. To take something as simple as 'garbage' essentially and turn it into a home for another is truly amazing. Just goes to show one man's trash really is another man's treasure (for the most part). Your first 2 questions are interesting but the third question is what brought me here. I would say the biggest thing they have in common is that they both noticed a problem and then took something that was not necessarily 'helping' in any real way or purpose anymore and innovated those things into something more valuable. Like the backpacks evolved into something that appeared more to the students as technology advanced the maker of paraSITE noticed trash bags that were just being thrown away with little to no 'value' left in them and turned them into homes for the less fortunate. One could argue one may be better than the other but as far as their value I'd agrue they have that in common as well if you look at the value of each product in comparison to the people they are trying to sell to.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Shane Riemer

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 11:41am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Is it really that innovative if one is really smashing one object, like a battery charger into a backpack? Or is it a lesser sort of innovation? What enables the reformulation of a concept, a leap that seemed previously unthinkable versus merely adding a new component to an existing product, which seems more like an upgrade? When art exists in new mediums, such as in a humanitarian manner, within the realm of social practice, is it really art? I would think so given the creativity and skill involved. However, where then do the bounds of art and not art lie?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Jan 21, 2016 Jan 21, 2016 at 11:12am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      A lot of people through time have tried to define innovation: is it new to me, new to my company, new to the customer, new to the world?  Sometimes people talk about breakthrough innovation versus incremental innovation to distinguish among these.  Here's what the dictionary says: a new method, idea, product, etc.  Not much help there, but at least an explanation as to why we are all confused!!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Jiachen Hu

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:44pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Hi Shane, these are some great questions! As for the first question, I would say the idea of merging two already existing products together is innovation, if only no one else had ever thought of that. However the process of innovation should not have stopped right after the idea. The idea has be turned into something presentable or practical so that people could actually benefit from it. In this case, the generating idea part was already done by countless of people in the past. However what Jansport did was to turn that into reality (I am not sure of that either..someone must have done it in the past). I would say the innovation consisted of thinking and making, the thinking part is usually where we focus on, but the making part is also essential to the whole process. Making something new idea into really, that update would be part of innovation. Just fixing problems using the same old method? That update would simply be an update then.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Stephanie Syjuco

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Jan 22, 2016 Jan 22, 2016 at 1:34pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Regarding the first question: Context is everything. Just smashing two things together isn't necessarily innovating or interesting, but IS when applied to a specific site, situation, question, or context and brings about a new way of seeing/using it. It may be helpful to focus on not just the abstract notion of "smashing things together" but how that is applied to a situation, and when.For the second question, one example could be the original Chinese invention of what would become gunpowder. However, it was used only for fireworks. It was the application by Europeans that applied it to become "gunpowder." I feel that that "turning" of use and meaning is not an upgrade but an applied invention.For the last question, if we begin to remove the "thingness" of how people assume art to behave (a painting, sculpture, object, item, etc) and begin think of it as a process with expanding boundaries, it definitely opens up a contemporary definition. When we think of the word "design" we think of an activity, a process, as much (or even more) than we even think of a final end-product. I hope that at some point the term "art" can become to be understood more like an active, creative verb as opposed to limited to an end object. Artists are already doing this and society, in a way, has to catch up on their definitions!What potentially separates "art" from anything else is the context and situation in which the maker positions it. Much like how I mention innovation earlier in this response.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Regarding the first question: Context is everything. Just smashing two things together isn't necessarily innovating or interesting, but IS when applied to a specific site, situation, question, or context and brings about a new way of seeing/using it. It may be helpful to focus on not just the abstract notion of "smashing things together" but how that is applied to a situation, and when.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            For the second question, one example could be the original Chinese invention of what would become gunpowder. However, it was used only for fireworks. It was the application by Europeans that applied it to become "gunpowder." I feel that that "turning" of use and meaning is not an upgrade but an applied invention.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            For the last question, if we begin to remove the "thingness" of how people assume art to behave (a painting, sculpture, object, item, etc) and begin think of it as a process with expanding boundaries, it definitely opens up a contemporary definition. When we think of the word "design" we think of an activity, a process, as much (or even more) than we even think of a final end-product. I hope that at some point the term "art" can become to be understood more like an active, creative verb as opposed to limited to an end object. Artists are already doing this and society, in a way, has to catch up on their definitions!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            What potentially separates "art" from anything else is the context and situation in which the maker positions it. Much like how I mention innovation earlier in this response.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Harneet Kaur

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 26, 2016 Feb 26, 2016 at 12:22pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Personally, I think social practice art is just as valuable as traditional art pieces.  But I think we are comparing them incorrectly.  The way I see it, it is an apples to oranges situation.  While both are fruits (both are art forms), they are clearly different in many ways and should not be compared in the same spaces because they are very different from one another.  The way I see it, to be able to appreciate both of these art forms, we need to provide them with different mediums of expression.  Traditional art is in museums/expos, so how might we display social-practice art?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        How much room is left for innovation within a certain market, for example, with backpacks? 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        How can one keep innovating within a certain market without over engineering an item? 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Donovan Souza

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 2:03pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Hey Jacqueline! I read a book last semester for UGBA 162: Brand Strategy and Management called Different: Escaping the Competitive Herd by Youngme Moon. The book goes in depth on several interesting business concepts, but the two that are most applicable here would be Reverse-positioned brands and Break-away brands. You can read a short article about the two here.  Reverse brands essentially cut back on features that consumers have grown accustomed to, in a way that is unique and works. The best example I can give is the emergence of the internet and sites like Yahoo.com and aol.com. Early in its formation, these websites drove traffic by cluttering their landing page with anything and everything (Weather news, sports news, local news, customizable pages, email, etc.). This was the norm for a while, until Google came about. Google is an example of a reverse-brand, they flipped search engine landing pages on their heads and provided a clean and mostly empty page for people to use. Reverse-brands can take existing innovations and alter them in a way that makes it simpler, while still being innovative. Breakaway brands move a product or innovation from one category and merge it with another. A good example I can think of is a robot pet. In reality, this innovation here is a robot, but has been crossed over into the category of pets. Studies showed that people treated the robot the same as they would a pet, and in this way the company that created this robot broke-away from typical robot stereotypes and gave consumers something else they were not expecting. I hope these two concepts give a different perspective on how one can innovate without simply adding more features to something!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Hey Jacqueline! I read a book last semester for UGBA 162: Brand Strategy and Management called Different: Escaping the Competitive Herd by Youngme Moon. The book goes in depth on several interesting business concepts, but the two that are most applicable here would be Reverse-positioned brands and Break-away brands. You can read a short article about the two here (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Reverse brands essentially cut back on features that consumers have grown accustomed to, in a way that is unique and works. The best example I can give is the emergence of the internet and sites like Yahoo.com and aol.com. Early in its formation, these websites drove traffic by cluttering their landing page with anything and everything (Weather news, sports news, local news, customizable pages, email, etc.). This was the norm for a while, until Google came about. Google is an example of a reverse-brand, they flipped search engine landing pages on their heads and provided a clean and mostly empty page for people to use. Reverse-brands can take existing innovations and alter them in a way that makes it simpler, while still being innovative.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Breakaway brands move a product or innovation from one category and merge it with another. A good example I can think of is a robot pet. In reality, this innovation here is a robot, but has been crossed over into the category of pets. Studies showed that people treated the robot the same as they would a pet, and in this way the company that created this robot broke-away from typical robot stereotypes and gave consumers something else they were not expecting.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            I hope these two concepts give a different perspective on how one can innovate without simply adding more features to something!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Ryan Ong

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:13pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              There is some hypocrisy here: doesn’t adding more separate accessories further encourage the bundling together of wires inside the backpack due to convenience? Aren’t they perhaps taking the wrong perspective? Don’t people stuff in their power cords for speed and simplicity? The “burrito” takes time and precision. If the developments of backpacks have gone stagnant, then why try to push it further as a “backpack”? Wouldn’t be far smarter for a company to expand their production into other products? Why are we so divisive about our definitions of culture? Why do we find the need to categorize what is anything in the first place? What if there was a future where categorization was not necessary? Random questions: Don’t the vents used by paraSITE’s eject dirty air? What does “a reaction to the art market’s distorting power, fueled by a concentration of international wealth” refer exactly to?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Irene Lee

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 8:02pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  As for #2, I also wonder that often. But I always hear that people inherently categorize/classify everything they can. Maybe it's a way of establishing some order, and create an illusion that we have control over something (that is actually too big so we can only dream of possessing any control over it). Then again, it seems that categorization are often scenario-dependent. Field-dependent? Just - dependent on a lot of factors.  Like if we had to categorize art, we could categorize it with a business manner, or we could try with a creative spirit, and you would end up with different category names that art would fall under. Categories definitely make discussion easier, clearer, so it's not always a nuisance. Just because something is categorized as one thing doesn't mean it can't be categorized as another, right? Such fluidity should be allowed.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Joy Lin

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:22pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The Ghana think tank situation was hilarious. At first I thought to myself that is utterly genius! But then as they were answering I realized that those in different countries probably did not fully comprehend the circumstance or issues those Americans were going through. It is sort of like having your aunt trying to help you solve an issue with your sister rather than your mom coming up with a solution. Your aunt wouldn't be able to understand fully the circumstance of your home. What do you guys think about that method of problem solving? How do you think culture determines what we deem to be both problems and solutions? I think that the New York Times backpack article was a really interesting comparison to the ghana think tank because all the problems and ideas concerning backpacks are so cultural. I wonder what solution people in ghana would have for us struggling to carry our technology and pens in a eco-friendly, stylish, business encouraging manner. When that article talked about how backpacks are becoming more acceptable in the working world I recalled discussions in class about how cultural dictates society so much. What does it matter if you make an amazing product if people don't want to wear it because it doesn't look cool? It is clear to me that ultimately the paraSITE project is ultimately an art project. I personally think that because it was created by an artist and is featured at the MOMA that it becomes more of a visual social commentary and an aesthetic sculpture than an effective policy to address homelessness. I think that is okay because it is powerful in the form that it is but I think others from a different practice rather than an artistic one might criticize it as a business failure or a social failure because only 30 were distributed. What do you guys think about this idea? Do you think that though projects can effectively combine may practices they usually can satisfy the intentions of only one practice?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The guy who created the paraSITE project is so clearly an artist based on his other work and what he says about his practice, "As an artistic gesture I try to make an unlikely thing happen, and the impossible becomes possible. It's art because it's impossible for this to exist in the world." (Michael Rakowitz)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:36pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              In the reading, different kinds of innovation are always fulfilling people's need, and are trying to catch of with changes (such as new backpack designs fulfill people's need for a more suitable backpack, artists now start to serve people instead of giving presentation, hip-hop music fulfills the communities' needs), but is it possible that innovation can play the role of changing our lifestyle? In most of the reading, innovation is tailed for a small group of people (homeless people, Ghana citizens, etc), are there any innovations that influence everyone?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Dennis Orason

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 2:02pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I think there have been many innovations in history that have affected or influenced everyone at one particular point in time. For instance, everyone who is alive today was born. As obvious and simple as that sounds, the methods in which childbirth and hospital care have been innovated in the last 100 years have probably made the process much cleaner, and safer. I feel like innovation is so heavily tied to the idea of "things" that the "ideas" are often overlooked. Imagine a world where no one ever considered the idea of social equity!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Ikya Kandula

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Jan 20, 2016 Jan 20, 2016 at 12:51pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. Something that has always really confused and inspired me about innovation is how the need to innovate arises. It always feels like there's some sort of internal motivation as with the paraSITE project and social practice art, but there are also cases of corporates innovating to make more money. So is there really intrinsic difference in innovating for social value and solving a need you see in the world or just for the sake of generating revenue?  2. For the Ghana project, it seems like interviewing clients/stakeholders is super integral for these projects to succeed. What sort of questions are you supposed to ask without being biased with a Western mindset? I also have heard a lot about projects that end up bringing unforeseen consequences that ruin the area even more, so how do you negate that with interviews?

Something that has always really confused and inspired me about innovation is how the need to innovate arises. It always feels like there's some sort of internal motivation as with the paraSITE project and social practice art, but there are also cases of corporates innovating to make more money. I also have heard a lot about projects that end up bringing unforeseen consequences that ruin the area even more, so how do you negate that with interviews?
